Def.Name: Amur Maple
Def.Description: Large shrub or small tree, 15' - 18' in height; round to irregular crown. It can be grown as a multistemmed clump or trained into a small tree with a single trunk. It can also be sheared into a hedge.
Def.Leaves: Simple, opposite; 1 2/2" - 3" long and usually less than one-third as wide, and coarsely toothed. Middle lobe much larger than lateral lobes; dark green, bright red or orange in autumn.
Def.Twigs: Yellowish-brown, slightly angled; buds, reddish-brown, small 1/8" long.
Def.SeedConeOrFruit: Fruit: Samaras are 3/4" to 1" long, held in small panicles and are red to brown in color.
Def.Bark: Smooth and gray on young branches and grayish brown on older branches. Becoming vertically striped.
Def.Range: Hardy to zone 3a. Is native to Manchuria, north China and Japan and is cultivated in gardens and parks.
Def.Remarks: As of 2008, it was considered as potentially invasive in Connecticut. The young leaves were used as a tea substitute.
